Summary:
The patient is an 85-year-old male with a history of coronary artery disease, who presented to the hospital after experiencing a cardiac arrest. The patient was initially in pulseless electrical activity (PEA) arrest and then converted to ventricular tachycardia (VT) before arriving at the emergency department. He was intubated and started on amiodarone drip post-arrest. The differential diagnosis for the PEA arrest includes cardiac ischemia, pulmonary embolism, heart failure, primary electrical disease, intracranial hemorrhage, and tamponade. There is no evidence of hypovolemia/bleeding, hyper/hypokalemia, medication overdoses, or trauma. Acidosis was evident on arrival to the ED, but it may have been a result of the arrest rather than the cause of it.

The patient underwent cooling with the Arctic sun and has shown some improvement. However, his neurologic function remains poor, with absent corneal reflexes, no response to cold calorics, and no response to noxious stimuli. The neurology team is following up on this concern for anoxic brain injury. The patient does not appear to have brainstem reflexes.

The patient's cardiac history includes coronary artery disease (CAD) status post coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG) in 2143 and redo CABG in 2152. He also had an aortic valve replacement (AVR) with a bioprosthetic valve. The cardiac catheterization revealed distal left anterior descending (LAD) disease treated with percutaneous transluminal coronary angioplasty (POBA). Troponins are uptrending, and the creatine kinase (CK) peaked at 1120 and is now downtrending.

The patient's rhythm is currently atrial fibrillation on telemetry, and he is not on coumadin at the outpatient level due to frequent falls. The patient's hemodynamics on the catheterization were not assessed, so an echocardiogram will be done in the morning.

The patient has a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus, chronic renal failure with baseline renal function of 1.5, and constrictive pericarditis reportedly with a history of stripping. He is currently NPO and will have an orogastric tube placed while intubated. Nutrition will be considered for total parenteral nutrition (TPN) recommendations. Electrolytes will be closely monitored and repleted as needed.

The patient has right femoral line and right femoral arterial line access. Prophylaxis is being given for deep vein thrombosis (DVT), stress ulcer, and ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP).

The patient's code status is full code, and his disposition is to the CCU. The contact information for his daughter, granddaughter, grandson, and another person is provided.

In summary, the patient is an elderly male with a history of CAD and recent cardiac arrest. He is currently in atrial fibrillation and has poor neurologic function. His cardiac history includes CABG, AVR, and treatment of distal LAD disease. The patient also has diabetes, chronic renal failure, and constrictive pericarditis. He is receiving appropriate medical management, including pressors, antibiotics, and anticoagulation therapy. The potential medical complications that can arise include further deterioration of neurologic function, cardiac arrhythmias, heart failure, and infection.
